parameters: Actor2
Hi Raphaëll! Welcome in.
Actor2
Your GP prescribed you a tubal ligation.
Can you tell me why you want that specific
contraception method?
Reduce mental workload
Political Stance
Reduce mental workload
Raph
I’ve known I was childfree since I was a
young teenager.
Raph
I don’t see the point in staying fertile,
knowing I won’t ever have children.
Raph
It just gives me an extra mental workload
with no benefit whatsoever, and I would
like to take it off my mind permanently.
Political Stance
Raph
I’ve known I was childfree since I was a
young teenager.
Raph
It would feel good to me to have my body
in line with my wants.
Raph
And it would send a clear message to anyone
who thinks I’ll change my mind someday, or
that anyone assigned female at birth deep
down actually wants children.
Raph
Also, it would protect me from any change
in reproductive rights, which is sadly a
real concern.
Raph
This is not an impulsive decision. I gave
myself until I was at least 25 to make up
my mind about it.
Raph
I know it might sound silly, but I picked
that age partly because that’s around when
the brain stops developing.
Raph
Also, I figured no one would take me
seriously before that age.
Raph
Although I have to say, I had little hope
until recently that any health practitioner
would take me seriously before I was well
into my 40s.
Actor2
I hear you. Don’t worry, here, age is not
an issue.
Raph
(I know! That’s why I picked her. I found
her on a childfree-friendly doctors list
on reddit)
Actor2
There are a few things to consider before
we move forward with that decision.
Actor2
For instance, what if you end up with
someone who wants children?
I'm not their incubator
We would break up
There are other ways
I'm not their incubator
Actor2
Oh, hum, no, that's not what I was trying
to imply of course.
Actor2
I understand why you would take offense in
that question.
Actor2
Just so you know, I'm asking precisely
because it's a situation I've seen happen
before. More than once.
Actor2
And then, it's an expensive and troublesome
medical hassle, trying to get the person
pregnant through IVF or something of the
likes.
Actor2
And it's heartbreaking when it doesn't work.
We would break up
Raph
It's a pretty big dealbreaker for me. I'm
childfree, regardless of what my partner
wants.
Raph
I actually just probably wouldn't get with
them it the first place.
Actor2
Yes of course.
Raph
Although, my thoughts have evolved on that
in the last few years. I'm polyamorous, and
while I wouldn't have my own children, I
don't mind if a partner wants to have
Raph
children with someone else. Or by themself.
Actor2
...I've never seen that in my practice, but
if that makes sense to you, that's all that
matters.
There are other ways
Raph
Even if I did change my mind, which I doubt
I ever would, there are other ways to have
children which are just as valid. I could
adopt. Or foster kids.
Actor2
Of course! There is more than one way to
start a family.
Raph
(I already have a family, and that wording
is pretty amatonormative and annoys me,
but I get what she means and it comes from
a good place).
(Note from Raphaëll from the future: my thoughts
regarding adoption changed a lot, and I think adoption
is an ethical minefield. I would not go down that route
even if I wanted kids)
Actor2
I only perform a non-reversible version of
this surgery on my patients. In the regular
version, we cut and tie the tubes so that
the egg cannot get to the womb and cannot
Actor2
be fertilized. It's hard to reverse, but
not entirely impossible. Some patients put
too much trust into the possibility of
reversing it one day.
Actor2
Then they change their mind, and we're
unable to reverse it, and it becomes a
much harder process to make them pregnant.
Actor2
I want my patients to be 100% sure they
want it, and I offer no way back. My
version of the procedure completely get
rid of the tubes.
Actor2
Are you ok with this?
Yes, it would give me dysphoria
Yes, I'm an antinatalist
Yes, it would give me dysphoria
Raph
Beyond not wanting children, I absolutely
do not want a pregnancy. I'm non-binary,
and I can't imagine an experience that
would be more dysphoria-inducing.
Raph
I'm 99% sure I don't want children.
I'm 100% sure I don't want to be pregnant
ever.
Actor2
Oh I didn't know about that. I'll write a
note in your record that you're non-binary
and to not use gendered titles with you, if
that's what you'd prefer.
Raph
Yes, I'd very much like that. Thank you
for offering.
Actor2
I definitely see how a pregnancy would be
a very undesired experience for you.
Yes, I'm an antinatalist
Raph
So this is a pretty big topic to go over,
but I'm very much antinatalist.
Raph
I think there's no harm done in *not*
bringing someome to life, but there's
potential harm done in bringing someone to
life. It's not a great gamble.
Raph
Plus, you can't get the person's consent to
create them. I know, I know, it's a
weird ethical stance, but having children
sounds like a questionable choice to me.
Actor2
It is a peculiar stance, but I hear you and
it does sound like you're pretty set on not
having children.
Actor2
There's one last thing I want us to go
over.
Actor2
There are other contraception methods that
are very effective, and don't require you
to undergo an invasive, irreversible
surgery.
Actor2
While I'm certainly not opposed to proceed
with a salpingectomy, I want my patients to
know the other options, to have explored
them already and make an enlighten choice.
Actor2
What other methods have you tried?
Condoms
Birth Pill
IUD
Condoms
Raph
I've been using condoms ever since I
started being sexually active.
Raph
They work great, and I intend on keeping to
use them even after surgery since I'm
non-monogamous.
Raph
Its failure rate is too high for me to
feel comfortable relying purely on it tho.
Actor2
That makes sense! If you want more effecti-
veness, you could just combine it with a
non-permanent method like the pill or an
IUD though.
The pill sucks
IUDs suck
The pill sucks
Raph
I've used the pill for a while. It had
disastrous side-effets on my mood and my
overall mental health.
Raph
I was super irritable, and often depressed.
I feel much better since I stopped.
Actor2
That's understandable. Lots of people have
a pretty negative experience with the pill.
Actor2
There is one last convenient option that
seems to be best of both worlds for you:
an IUD.
Actor2
It's one of the most reliable birth control
out there, and you wouldn't have the side-
effects that come with the pill.
Raph
So with a copper IUD, your cramps and blee-
ding from your periods intensify.
Raph
I don't have very painful periods or a huge
flow, but I'd still rather not make them
more inconvenient if I can.
Raph
And given my history with the birth control
pill, I wouldn't give hormonal IUDs a try.
Actor2
I have to say, the amount of hormones found
in an IUD are very very low. You have low
chances of experiencing the same problems.
Raph
That's good to know. I'm pretty set on
getting rid of my tubes though. I would be
very affirming for me to have a permanent
method of contraception.
Raph
And I would never have to think about it
again.
Actor2
Ok. Here's what I'll offer you:
Actor2
Here's a pamphlet on IUDs. I'd really like
for you to take a week or two to think
about it and seriously consider this
option.
Actor2
An IUD is very low maintenance. You just
have to change it every 5 years, and then
you don't need to worry about it for the
next 5 years.
Actor2
It has most of the benefits of a salpin-
gectomy, on top of being reversible.
Actor2
Plus, a hormonal one would actually
decrease the effects of your period, which
I hear are not that bad but are still an
inconvenience.
Actor2
If in a week, you're still very confident
about wanting the salpingectomy and nothing
else, then I'll happily proceed with it.
Actor2
Does that sound good to you?
Raph
Yeah, it does. Let's do things that way.
IUDs suck
Raph
So with a copper IUD, your cramps and blee-
ding from your periods intensify.
Raph
I don't have very painful periods or a huge
flow, but I'd still rather not make them
more inconvenient if I can.
Actor2
And what about a hormonal IUD?
Raph
Eh, I had a very horrible experience with
the birth control pill, and I'd rather
avoid any contraception that is hormone-
based.
Raph
I was super irritable, and often depressed.
I feel much better since I stopped.
Actor2
That's understandable. Lots of people have
a pretty negative experience with the pill.
Actor2
Although I have to say, the amount of
hormones found in an IUD are very very low.
You have low chances of experiencing the
same problems, whatever they were.

Actor1
Actor1_1
People1
Good afternoon Erwan.
People1
I read here in your file that your doctor
prescribed you a vasectomy.
Is that correct?
Actor1
That's correct.
People1
You know that conjugality changes, right?
Actor1
Excuse me?
People1
I mean, you know you might break-up and be
with someone else in the future?
Yes
Yes
People1
Good, good.
People1
And you are aware that this is a permanent
method of contraception?
Yes
Yes
People1
Excellent.
People1
Some people assume it's reversible. It is
to some degree, but there is a significant
number of men who reverse their vasectomy
and are infertile.
People1
The longer you are vasectomized, the higher
the chances that you can't ever conceive a
child.
People1
But if you're aware of all of that, we can
proceed. I'm adding you to the waitlist.
You'll be called when it'll be your turn.
